revisions.rev:
'''Right-wing''' is the opposite to left-wing, with both terms originating in the [[French Revolution]] as discussed in the article on [[leftism]].
Traditionally the right-wing defends the traditional power of aristocrats, royalty, established religions and the wealthy, as opposed to movements promoting equal rights or wealth for all. The term has also come to be used for [[nationalist]] or [[racist]] movements which favour the interests of a majority in the population against minority groups, with [[fascism]] or [[nazism]] the canonical examples.
Some usages of the term [[conservatism]] are also considered to be right-wing, by leftists. Liberals and other leftist often consider themselves "moderate".
Support for [[free market]] [[economic]]s has at times been classed as both right and left-wing. It was left-wing during the French Revolution, since the concept is opposed to the kind of economic favouritism practiced by the elite in that country at the time. In theory anyone has an equal chance in a free market. However in practice, a free market is likely (some say mathematically inevitable) to result in large variations in the relative prosperity of individuals, with almost all of the real power (wealth, in a free market) held by a small percentage of the population. Hence, it can also be considered a doctrine of the right-wing.
